text: data must contain required columns soil measurement must column, shown washi_data.

title: Import your data
text: data must required columns. However, columns bold required values. Put another way, data must column names, even every row blank. year <int> used select samples included report. sample_id <chr> unique identifier soil sample. Can alphanumeric value combination year, producer_id, field_id. farm_name <chr> included top report. blank, replaced ‚ÄúFarm: producer_id‚Äù. producer_id <chr> unique identifier producer. Reports generated producer_id within given year. can alphanumeric value producer‚Äôs name. field_id <chr> distinguish fields producer multiple samples year. Must unique within producer_id year combination. Can alphanumeric value producer-assigned field name. county <chr> used group summarize samples county producer. Can blank. crop <chr> used group summarize samples crop producer. Can blank. latitude <int> longitude <int>used map sample point. blank, map included. Coordinates must provided decimal degrees. latitude may range -90 90. longitude may range -180 180. soil measurement must column dataset corresponding row data dictionary, shown Dictionary template.

what: Measurement results (columns J‚ÄìAO: texture through na_mg_kg)
title: Import your data
text: measurement columns except texture must numeric. Non-numeric values (e.g., ND, <1) coerced NA may omitted summaries, tables, plots. Clean recode censored values uploading. texture may left blank. least two sand_percent, silt_percent, clay_percent provided, texture classified using USDA NRCS rules. sand_percent, silt_percent, clay_percent must: 0 100 Sum 100 (¬± 1) Include least two values per sample (third calculated 100 minus sum two) Delete columns measurements analyzed project. Add columns additional measurements wish include. Important: Measurement column names data must match exactly match column_name values data_dictionary. Update data_dictionary adding removing measurements.

title: Import your data
text: data dictionary used group order soil measurements, nicely format labels tables plots. example data_dictionary contains UTF-8 encoded superscripts, subscripts, special characters. properly encode data dictionary UTF-8, save data folder CSV UTF-8 (Comma delimited) (*.csv) MS Excel.  data dictionary must required columns every soil measurement included data. measurement_group <chr> defines soil measurements grouped. Groups appear report order listed data dictionary. following values currently supported. Custom groups allowed fail validation. English: Physical, Biological, Chemical, Plant Essential Macro Nutrients, Plant Essential Micro Nutrients Spanish: Mediciones f√≠sicas, Mediciones biol√≥gicas, Mediciones qu√≠micas, Macronutrientes esenciales para plantas, Micronutrientes esenciales para plantas column_name <chr> used join dictionary data. Must exactly match column names soil measurements data. Within measurement group, measurements appear order listed data dictionary. abbr <chr>: Abbreviation used tables plots. Shorter abbreviations improve readability. unit <chr>: Unit measurement displayed tables plots. abbr + unit: Combination abbreviation unit must unique measurement.
code: dplyr::glimpse(data_dictionary) #> Rows: 32 #> Columns: 4 #> $ measurement_group <chr> "Physical", "Physical", "Physical", "Physical", "Phy‚Ä¶ #> $ column_name       <chr> "texture", "sand_percent", "silt_percent", "clay_per‚Ä¶ #> $ abbr              <chr> "Texture", "Sand", "Silt", "Clay", "Bulk Density", "‚Ä¶ #> $ unit              <chr> "", "%", "%", "%", "g/cm¬≥", "%", "in/ft", "%", "mg/k‚Ä¶

title: Import your data
text: {soils} version 1.0.1, measurement columns automatically detected, converted numeric, pivoted tidy long format. measurement columns must numeric. Non-numeric values (e.g., ND, <1, NA, blanks, characters) coerced NA may omitted summaries, tables, plots. additional metadata columns converted pivoted, add metadata_cols vector. See troubleshooting article help debugging errors.
code: # OPTIONAL EDIT: Add any extra metadata columns in `data` that should not be # treated as measurements. metadata_cols <- c(   "year",   "sample_id",   "farm_name",   "producer_id",   "field_id",   "county",   "crop",   "longitude",   "latitude",   "texture" )  # Identify measurement columns measurement_cols <- data |>   dplyr::select(-dplyr::any_of(metadata_cols)) |>   colnames()  # Coerce measurement columns to numeric; warns if values are converted to NA data <- soils::coerce_to_numeric(data, measurement_cols)  # Tidy data into long format and join with data dictionary results_long <- data |>   tidyr::pivot_longer(     cols = dplyr::all_of(measurement_cols),     names_to = "measurement"   ) |>   ...

title: Visualize and Report Soil Health Data
text: {soils} R package soil health data visualization reporting needs. {soils} provides RStudio project template generate customized, interactive soil health reports. reports include plots tables show participant‚Äôs results compare simple averages results samples crop, county, across entire project. scientist leading soil health survey can use {soils} create custom reports participants. Democratize data giving back farmers land managers contributed soil samples soil sampling project. Use reports empower participant explore better understand data. Defaults FALSE box. legend Character vector appear legend. color Character vector color points. pch Numeric vector plotting symbols. code: texture <- washi_data |>   dplyr::select(     sand = sand_percent,     silt = silt_percent,     clay = clay_percent   )  make_texture_triangle(body_font = "sans")  # Add gray points add_texture_points(   tail(texture, 5),   color = "#3E3D3D90",   pch = 19 )  # Add red points add_texture_points(   head(texture, 5),   color = "#a60f2dCC",   pch = 15 )  # Add legend add_legend(   legend = c("Red squares", "Gray circles"),   color = c("#a60f2dCC", "#3E3D3D90"),   pch = c(15, 19),   vertical_spacing = 2 )   # Note the text appears squished in this example since the width, height, # and resolution have been optimized to print the figure 6 in wide in the # report.

what: Classify USDA soil texture from particle-size fractions ‚Äî classify_texture
title: Classify USDA soil texture from particle-size fractions ‚Äî classify_texture
text: Validates soil particle-size fractions (sand, silt, clay), completes missing values possible, assigns USDA soil texture class.

title: Classify USDA soil texture from particle-size fractions ‚Äî classify_texture
code: classify_texture(df)

title: Classify USDA soil texture from particle-size fractions ‚Äî classify_texture
text: Thresholds texture classification based USDA NRCS Soil Texture Calculator.

title: Classify USDA soil texture from particle-size fractions ‚Äî classify_texture
text: df data frame containing columns sample_id, sand_percent, silt_percent, clay_percent. optional texture column can also provided.

title: Classify USDA soil texture from particle-size fractions ‚Äî classify_texture
text: data frame texture column containing USDA soil texture classes (enough soil fraction data provided). Soil fractions rounded whole numbers.

title: Classify USDA soil texture from particle-size fractions ‚Äî classify_texture
text: classify_texture() applies following validation rules assumptions: Eligibility sample must contain values least two sand_percent, silt_percent, clay_percent eligible fraction-based texture classification. Errors (cause validation fail) fraction values must fall within range 0‚Äì100. Samples three fractions must sum 100 ¬±1 tolerance (allowable range 99‚Äì101). Warnings (validation continues) exactly one fraction missing, calculated 100 - (sum two). Samples fewer two provided fractions provided texture sufficient data texture classification. samples retained returned NA texture value. Special cases (warning error) Samples fewer two provided fractions provided texture preserve texture without modification.

title: Classify USDA soil texture from particle-size fractions ‚Äî classify_texture
code: # Three samples classified without error  df <- data.frame(   sample_id = c(1, 2, 3),   sand_percent = c(20, 45, 75),   silt_percent = c(65, 35, 15),   clay_percent = c(15, 20, 10) )  classify_texture(df) #>   sample_id    texture sand_percent silt_percent clay_percent #> 1         1  Silt Loam           20           65           15 #> 2         2       Loam           45           35           20 #> 3         3 Sandy Loam           75           15           10  # Error when any fraction is outside the allowable range (0-100)  df <- data.frame(   sample_id = c(1, 2, 3),   sand_percent = c(40, 0, 65),   silt_percent = c(40, 55, 5),   clay_percent = c(20, 110, 30) )  try(classify_texture(df)) #> Error : ‚úñ Soil texture validation failed. #>  #> Soil fractions are provided in the columns sand_percent, clay_percent, and #> silt_percent. #>  #> ‚Ñπ Samples with errors to correct: #> ‚Ä¢ Sample 2 must have all fraction values between 0 and 100. #> ‚Ä¢ Sample 2 must have fractions that sum to 100 (+/- 1).  # Error when fractions do not sum to 100 +/- 1 (allowable range: 99-101)  df <- data.frame(   sample_id = c(1, 2, 3),   sand_percent = c(40, 0, 90),   silt_percent = c(40, 55, 5),   clay_percent = c(20, 45, 30) )  try(classify_texture(df)) #> Error : ‚úñ Soil texture validation failed. #>  #> Soil fractions are provided in the columns sand_percent, clay_percent, and #> silt_percent. #>  #> ‚Ñπ Samples with errors to correct: #> ‚Ä¢ Sample 3 must have fractions that sum to 100 (+/- 1).  # Warn when one fraction is missing # The missing fraction is calculated as 100 minus the other two  df <- data.frame(   sample_id = c(1, 2, 3),   sand_percent = c(NA, 60, 25),   silt_percent = c(45, 10, 40),   clay_percent = c(50, 30, 35) )  classify_texture(df) #> Warning: ! Soil texture validation completed with assumptions. #>  #> Soil fractions are provided in the columns sand_percent, clay_percent, and #> silt_percent. #>  #> ‚Ñπ Samples with assumptions: #> ‚Ä¢ Sample 1 is missing one fraction and will be calculated as 100 minus the #>   other two. #>   sample_id         texture sand_percent silt_percent clay_percent #> 1         1      Silty Clay            5           45           50 #> 2         2 Sandy Clay Loam           60           10           30 #> 3         3       Clay Loam           25           40           35  # Warn when a sample has insufficient data and classification is skipped # One sample is missing two soil fractions  df <- data.frame(   sample_id = c(1, 2, 3),   sand_percent = c(40, NA, 65),   silt_percent = c(40, 55, 5),   clay_percent = c(20, NA, 30) )  classify_texture(df) #> Warning: ! Soil texture validation completed with assumptions. #>  #> Soil fractions are provided in the columns sand_percent, clay_percent, and #> silt_percent. #>  #> ‚Ñπ Samples with assumptions: #> ‚Ä¢ Sample 2 has fewer than two fractions and will be skipped during texture #>   classification. #>   sample_id         texture sand_percent silt_percent clay_percent #> 1         1            Loam           40           40           20 #> 2         2            <NA>           NA           55           NA #> 3         3 Sandy Clay Loam           65            5           30  # No fractions provided, but texture is supplied # No warning; existing texture is preserved  df <- data.frame(   sample_id = c(1, 2),   sand_percent = c(NA, NA),   silt_percent = c(NA, NA),   clay_percent = c(NA, NA),   texture = c("Loam", "Sandy loam") )  classify_texture(df) #>   sample_id sand_percent silt_percent clay_percent    texture #> 1         1           NA           NA           NA       Loam #> 2         2           NA           NA           NA Sandy loam

title: Convert a ggplot2 plot to an interactive ggiraph ‚Äî convert_ggiraph
code:
# Read in wrangled example plot data df_plot_path <- soils_example("df_plot.RDS") df_plot <- readRDS(df_plot_path)  # Make strip plot with all measurements and set scales based on # the category column and then apply theme.  # Subset df to just biological measurement group df_plot_bio <- df_plot |>   dplyr::filter(measurement_group == "Biological")  # NOTE: the plot gets piped into the `set_scales()` function, which gets # added to `theme_facet_strip()`. plot <- make_strip_plot(   df_plot_bio,   x = dummy,   y = value,   id = sample_id,   group = abbr_unit,   tooltip = label,   color = category,   fill = category,   size = category,   alpha = category,   shape = category ) |>   set_scales() +   theme_facet_strip(body_font = "sans")  # Convert static plot to interactive `ggiraph` convert_ggiraph(plot) #> Can't find font family `Poppins` on your system. #> ‚Ñπ Defaulting to a sans-serif font. #> ‚Ñπ See the ggiraph book (<https://www.ardata.fr/ggiraph-book/fonts.html>) for #>   help.  {"x":{"html":"<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

what: Convert measurement columns to numeric and warn on coercion ‚Äî convert_to_numeric
title: Convert measurement columns to numeric and warn on coercion ‚Äî convert_to_numeric
text: Intended use data ingestion validation reporting workflow.

title: Convert measurement columns to numeric and warn on coercion ‚Äî convert_to_numeric
code: convert_to_numeric(data, measurement_cols)

title: Convert measurement columns to numeric and warn on coercion ‚Äî convert_to_numeric
text: data data frame containing metadata quantitative measurement columns. measurement_cols character vector column names convert numeric.

title: Convert measurement columns to numeric and warn on coercion ‚Äî convert_to_numeric
text: data frame specified measurement columns coerced numeric.

title: Convert measurement columns to numeric and warn on coercion ‚Äî convert_to_numeric
text: Non-numeric values specified measurement columns, character values commonly used represent missing censored measurements (e.g. "ND", "<1", "-", ""), coerced NA. Warnings emitted non-missing values coerced NA, column contains NA values coercion, indicating may omitted downstream summaries visualizations.

title: Convert measurement columns to numeric and warn on coercion ‚Äî convert_to_numeric
code: # Example data example_data <- data.frame(   year        = c(2023, 2023, 2024),   sample_id   = c("S1", "S2", "S3"),   field_id    = c("A", "A", "B"),   ph          = c("6.5", "ND", "7.1"),   # partial NA (1 ND -> NA)   nh4_n_mg_kg = c("12.3", "<1", ""),     # partial NA (2 non-numeric -> NA)   no3_n_mg_kg = c("NA", "NA", "NA"),     # fully NA   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )   # Specify the measurement columns measurement_cols = c("ph", "nh4_n_mg_kg", "no3_n_mg_kg")  # Convert measurement columns to numeric clean_data <- convert_to_numeric(example_data, measurement_cols) #> Warning: ‚Ñπ Non-numeric values were converted to `NA`. (e.g., `ND` or `<1`). These values #>   are excluded from tables and plots. #>  #> ! Columns with values converted to `NA`: #> ‚Ä¢ ph (1 value) #> ‚Ä¢ nh4_n_mg_kg (2 values) #> ‚Ä¢ no3_n_mg_kg (3 values)

title: Make a facetted strip plot ‚Äî make_strip_plot

title: Make a facetted strip plot ‚Äî make_strip_plot
text: df Data frame plot. ... arguments passed graphics::points(). x Column x-axis. strip plots, recommend using dummy variable act placeholder. Defaults column named dummy one value ("dummy") rows. y Column y-axis. Defaults value. id Column unique identifiers sample use data_id interactive plots. Defaults sample_id. group Column facet . Defaults abbr_unit. tooltip Column tooltip labels interactive plots. language Language legend. "English" (default) "Spanish".

title: Make a facetted strip plot ‚Äî make_strip_plot
text: Facetted ggplot2 strip plots.

title: Make a facetted strip plot ‚Äî make_strip_plot
code: # Read in wrangled example plot data df_plot_path <- soils_example("df_plot.RDS") df_plot <- readRDS(df_plot_path)  # Subset df to just biological measurement group df_plot_bio <- df_plot |>   dplyr::filter(measurement_group == "Biological")  # Make strip plot with all measurements and set scales based on # the category column and then apply theme.  # NOTE: the plot gets piped into the `set_scales()` function, which gets # added to `theme_facet_strip()`.  make_strip_plot(   df_plot_bio,   x = dummy,   y = value,   id = sample_id,   group = abbr_unit,   tooltip = label,   color = category,   fill = category,   size = category,   alpha = category,   shape = category ) |>   set_scales() +   theme_facet_strip(body_font = "sans")   # Example of strip plot without scales or theme functions make_strip_plot(df_plot_bio)   # Example of strip plot with `x` set to the facet group instead of a dummy # variable. The dummy variable is what centers the points within the subplot. make_strip_plot(   df_plot_bio,   x = abbr_unit,   y = value,   id = sample_id,   group = abbr_unit,   tooltip = label,   color = category,   fill = category,   size = category,   alpha = category,   shape = category ) |>   set_scales() +   theme_facet_strip(body_font = "sans")

title: Theme for facetted strip plots ‚Äî theme_facet_strip
code: # Read in wrangled example plot data df_plot_path <- soils_example("df_plot.RDS") df_plot <- readRDS(df_plot_path)  # Subset df to just biological measurement group df_plot_bio <- df_plot |>   dplyr::filter(measurement_group == "Biological")  # Make strip plot with all measurements and set scales based on # the category column and then apply theme.  # NOTE: the plot gets piped into the `set_scales()` function, which gets # added to `theme_facet_strip()`.  make_strip_plot(   df_plot_bio,   x = dummy,   y = value,   id = sample_id,   group = abbr_unit,   tooltip = label,   color = category,   fill = category,   size = category,   alpha = category,   shape = category ) |>   set_scales() +   theme_facet_strip(body_font = "sans")   # Example without setting theme make_strip_plot(   df_plot_bio,   x = dummy,   y = value,   id = sample_id,   group = abbr_unit,   tooltip = label,   color = category,   fill = category,   size = category,   alpha = category,   shape = category ) |>   set_scales()

title: Validate soil texture fractions ‚Äî validate_texture_fractions
text: Internal helper validates soil particle-size fractions (sand, silt, clay). exactly two three fraction columns present, missing column created filled NA later computed complete_texture_fractions(). Samples fewer two provided fractions retained skipped texture validation classification.

title: Validate soil texture fractions ‚Äî validate_texture_fractions
code: validate_texture_fractions(df)

title: Validate soil texture fractions ‚Äî validate_texture_fractions
text: df data frame containing sample_id least two sand_percent, silt_percent, clay_percent.

title: Validate soil texture fractions ‚Äî validate_texture_fractions
text: data frame validated soil texture fraction columns (sand_percent, silt_percent, clay_percent). exactly two fractions present, third created filled NA downstream completion.

title: Validate soil texture fractions ‚Äî validate_texture_fractions
text: Fractions rounded prior validation. Warns fewer two fractions provided exactly one fraction missing. Errors fraction values outside allowable range (0-100) complete fractions sum 100 (+/- 1).

title: soils (development version)
text: Remove field_name required column adjust templates, example data, vignettes. 01_producer-report.qmd now reads sample_id field_id character type, fixes unwanted commas numeric IDs (#10). Replaced internal testthat checks missing required columns custom cli-based helper, abort_if_missing_cols(), provide clearer, user-facing error messages (#14). Texture updates: Data upload longer requires pre-existing texture column. Added new texture helpers: validate_texture_fractions(), complete_texture_fractions(), classify_texture(). validate sand, silt, clay fractions, compute missing fraction exactly two provided, assign USDA soil texture classes possible. Updated internal helpers 01_producer-report.qmd template conditionally compute texture synchronize data dictionary texture fractions added (#21). Introduced sync_dictionary_texture() automatically add missing texture fraction rows dictionary fixed order (texture, sand_percent, silt_percent, clay_percent), support English Spanish labels. Deprecated get_n_texture_by_var(); logic now handled directly summarize_by_var(), treats texture optional. Fixed texture triangle rendering require least one complete sand, silt, clay sample. Incomplete texture rows now dropped early, preventing errors producer data include partial texture information (#15). Plot map updates: convert_ggiraph() uses gdtools::font_family_exists() instead ggiraph::font_family_exists(), longer exported ggiraph (#12). Added make_static_map() creating non-interactive maps using basemap tiles ggplot2 (#13). Removed dependency tidyterra static map rendering. Basemap tiles now plotted using ggplot2, improving stability reducing package dependencies. Static maps now request basemap tiles using buffered bounding box rather point geometries. improves robustness small single-point spatial extents prevents tile grid errors samples tightly clustered. Renamed make_leaflet() make_interactive_map() provide descriptive consistent naming convention alongside make_static_map(). make_leaflet() retained backwards compatibility. Measurement handling updates: Measurements must quantitative. Modified template dynamically select measurement columns (based provided vector metadata columns) (#24) coerce measurement columns numeric new function coerce_to_numeric() (#11 #26). Added footnote tables new function add_field_count_note() clarify field counts reflect total samples contributing average, may fewer total samples measurements now qualitative measurements coerced numeric.

title: soils 1.0.1
text: Pre-calculate zoom static map fix issue less 4 tiles (https://github.com/WA-Department--Agriculture/dirt-data-reports/issues/110) switch World Imagery instead Street Map.
